item.title: Interactive Maps with only CSS/HTML
item.description: Creating an interactive map with just HTML and CSS is something that should be possible. We just want to change the colors of certain parts of the map after they have been clicked. What makes certain maps hard? CSS allows for two color choices: checked and not checked. We would like more color choices. HTML likes rectangles and the U.S. does not consist of rectangular states. We really would like to display counts and CSS does not like adding user-generated numbers.

item.title: Interactive Web Pages using only CSS and HTML
item.description: Every web page on this domain is created using only HTML and CSS. No Javascript and no server interaction (other than navigating to a new static page). There is no good reason to make an interactive website completely static and avoid Javascript. Most of these web pages could be improved and made smaller by using just a few lines of Javascript because CSS is really not designed to do the things I use it for.

item.title: Sources for maps and political data
item.description: The default values for House races come from Sabato's crystal ball at UVA's Center for Politics. The partisan index for each district comes from Cook PVI. The congressional district maps come from this GitHub repository. Congressional campaign finance data comes from theFEC. Presidential election results by district come from Daily Kos. City locations for Travelling Salesman games come from Simple Maps.

item.title: Sudoku Game with only CSS/HTML
item.description: Sudoku is a relatively simple game to program in just about any programming language. Create a grid with 9 rows and columns and let the user input any number from 1-9 into each cell. But there are features that a computer makes possible that paper and pencil cannot match. One feature is blocking a user from inputting a number into row, column, or 3x3 block that already has that number. Another feature is to highlight the row, column, and 3x3 block of each cell to avoid any confusion.
